article_title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I
question: In the story, the magician tells Aladdin that finding the lamp will make him "richer than any king in the world."What does this phrase mean?
option_A: Aladdin will have more money than he can count
option_B: Aladdin will become the ruler of a kingdom
option_C: Aladdin will find gold coins in the cave
option_D: Aladdin will meet kings from other countries
option_A_explanation: You successfully made a good prediction by using clues about the magic lamp and treasure. The text supports this when it says the lamp “had amazing powers that would make any person very rich” and the magician promises it “will make you richer than any king in the world.” Remember to look for repeated hints and strong words like “will” to predict what will happen next.
option_B_explanation: You may have thought “richer than any king” means Aladdin becomes a king, or you used what you know from other versions, but the text says the lamp “would make any person very rich” and “It will make you richer than any king,” which is about money, not ruling. So the correct answer is that Aladdin will have more money than he can count. Strategy: Reread and underline clue words like “rich/richer,” and choose the answer that matches exactly what the passage says—not what you expect from outside the story.
option_C_explanation: You may have brought in outside ideas (gold coins), but the text never mentions coins—Aladdin finds “beautiful gems,” and the lamp is said to make a person “very rich,” even “richer than any king.” That means the best prediction is about how much wealth he will have, not a specific kind of money, so “Aladdin will have more money than he can count” fits the text. Next time, stick to the exact words and look for clue phrases about the main idea, like “very rich.”
option_D_explanation: You may have focused on the word “king” and guessed he’d meet kings, but the text never says Aladdin will meet any kings; it says the lamp “had amazing powers that would make any person very rich” and the treasure “will make you richer than any king in the world.” That evidence points to the correct answer: Aladdin will have more money than he can count. Strategy: reread for clue words and choose the option that matches what the passage actually says, not ideas it doesn’t mention.

article_title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I
question: What does the phrase 'the earth split open' describe in the story?
option_A: The ground cracked apart to reveal a hidden entrance
option_B: An earthquake happened on top of the mountain
option_C: The magician dug a deep hole in the dirt
option_D: Lightning struck the ground and made a crater
option_A_explanation: Correct! The text says 'The earth split open right at their feet' and then 'There in front of them lay a huge stone with a brass ring.' This phrase describes how the ground magically opened to show the entrance to the cave below. This is nonliteral language showing something magical happened.
option_B_explanation: Incorrect. While 'split open' might make you think of an earthquake, the text shows this was caused by the magician's spell, not a natural earthquake. The phrase is describing a magical event, not a natural disaster.
option_C_explanation: Incorrect. The magician did not dig anything. The text says he 'spoke magical words' and then 'the earth split open,' which means magic caused the ground to open, not physical digging.
option_D_explanation: Incorrect. While the text mentions 'Thunder crashed and rumbled,' it does not say lightning struck the ground. The phrase 'earth split open' describes the magical opening of the ground to reveal the stone covering the cave entrance.

article_title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I
question: According to the first paragraph, what does it mean that Aladdin's mother had to 'work hard to earn money'?
option_A: She had to do difficult jobs to pay for their needs
option_B: She had to learn how to make clothes like a tailor
option_C: She had to ask strangers to give her family money
option_D: She had to travel far away to find a better job
option_A_explanation: Correct! The text explains that after Aladdin's father died, 'Aladdin's mother had to work hard to earn money for food and shelter.' This phrase means she needed to do challenging work to get the money they needed to survive. The phrase 'work hard' is literal language meaning to put in great effort at a job.
option_B_explanation: Incorrect. The text does not say she became a tailor. It says his father 'worked as a tailor,' but we do not know what job the mother did. The phrase means she had to do difficult work, not specifically tailoring.
option_C_explanation: Incorrect. 'Work hard to earn money' means doing a job to get paid, not asking for money. Earning means getting money by working, which is different from asking people to give you money.
option_D_explanation: Incorrect. The text does not mention her traveling anywhere. The phrase 'work hard to earn money' describes putting effort into a job, not traveling to find one. She stayed and worked to support her family after her husband died.

article_title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I
question: What does the magician mean when he says the lamp 'had amazing powers that would make any person very rich'?
option_A: The lamp was made of expensive gold and jewels
option_B: The lamp contained magical abilities to create great wealth
option_C: The lamp could light up dark caves to find treasure
option_D: The lamp was very old and worth money to collectors
option_A_explanation: Incorrect. The text says the lamp 'had amazing powers,' which tells us the lamp itself was magical, not that it was made of expensive materials. The phrase is about what the lamp can do, not what it is made from.
option_B_explanation: Correct! The text explains the magician wanted 'a special magic lamp' and 'People said this lamp had amazing powers that would make any person very rich.' This nonliteral phrase means the lamp had supernatural or magical abilities that could create wealth for whoever owned it, not just that it was valuable.
option_C_explanation: Incorrect. While lamps do provide light, the phrase 'amazing powers that would make any person very rich' is describing magical abilities to create wealth, not just the normal function of lighting dark places.
option_D_explanation: Incorrect. The text emphasizes 'amazing powers' which indicates magic, not just being valuable because of age. The phrase is about the lamp's supernatural abilities to make someone wealthy, not its value as an antique.

article_title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I
question: Based on paragraph 3, what does the phrase 'the ground looked empty and bare' tell us about the location?
option_A: Nothing was growing or living in that place
option_B: The magician had cleared away all the plants earlier
option_C: A fire had burned down all the trees recently
option_D: The mountain was covered with snow and ice
option_A_explanation: Correct! The text says 'they reached a spot where no flowers or plants could grow. The ground looked empty and bare.' This phrase uses descriptive language to show that the place was lifeless and nothing grew there. 'Empty and bare' means there was nothing living or growing on the ground.
option_B_explanation: Incorrect. The text does not say the magician cleared plants away. The phrase 'empty and bare' describes the natural state of this location - that plants could not grow there at all, not that someone removed them.
option_C_explanation: Incorrect. There is no mention of a previous fire. The text explains 'no flowers or plants could grow' in this spot, meaning it was naturally barren, not that something destroyed plants that once grew there.
option_D_explanation: Incorrect. The text does not mention snow or ice. 'Empty and bare' means without plants or life, not covered with snow. The description is about the lack of vegetation, not about weather or snow cover.

article_title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I
question: What causes the magician to trap Aladdin in the cave?
option_A: Aladdin doesn't give him the lamp right away.
option_B: Aladdin won't to go into the cave.
option_C: Aladdin takes too many gems from the cave.
option_D: Aladdin breaks the magic ring on his finger.
option_A_explanation: You successfully understood cause and effect by noticing that Aladdin doesn’t give the lamp right away. The text supports this when the magician says, “First, hand me the lamp,” and Aladdin replies, “I cannot reach it right now.” Remember to reread what happens right before and after an event to see why it happens.
option_B_explanation: You may have thought Aladdin refused to go into the cave, but the story says he “agreed to help” and “went down into the dark cave below.” The problem is that “the lamp was buried deep in Aladdin’s heavy bag,” so he couldn’t reach it and didn’t give it to the magician right away—that’s why the correct answer is “Aladdin doesn’t give him the lamp right away.” Next time, reread and find the exact sentence in the text that answers the question.
option_C_explanation: You may have focused on the gems, but the text shows the problem happens when Aladdin won’t give the lamp right away: “First, hand me the lamp… The magician grew very angry,” and then he seals the cave. So the correct answer is that Aladdin doesn’t hand over the lamp right away. Next time, reread the sentences just before the trouble to find the real cause.
option_D_explanation: You may have brought in an idea that isn’t in this part of the story (the ring breaking), but look at the text: “First, hand me the lamp…,” “I cannot reach it right now,” and “The magician grew very angry,” which shows he’s mad because Aladdin doesn’t give him the lamp right away. The passage never says the ring breaks; it only says the ring will keep him safe. To find the right answer, reread the lines around the event and look for cause-and-effect clue words (like “first,” “when”), and choose the option that matches what the text directly says.

article_title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I
question: What shows that the magician's real goal is to get the lamp, not to help Aladdin?
option_A: He traps Aladdin when the boy cannot give him the lamp immediately
option_B: He gives Aladdin a magic ring to keep him safe in the cave
option_C: He takes Aladdin away from the city to climb a mountain
option_D: He tells Aladdin's mother that he wants to help the boy
option_A_explanation: Correct! The text shows the magician 'only cared about getting the magic lamp' and when Aladdin could not hand it over right away, 'He spoke a magic spell, and the stone rolled back into place. Poor Aladdin was trapped.' This action reveals his true selfish motivation - he traps Aladdin rather than helping him, showing he never cared about the boy.
option_B_explanation: Incorrect. Giving Aladdin the ring might seem helpful, but the text explains the magician 'needed someone to help him' get the lamp. He protected Aladdin only so the boy could complete the task, not because he truly cared about helping him.
option_C_explanation: Incorrect. Taking Aladdin to the mountain was necessary to reach the lamp's location, not evidence of his real goal. The text shows his true motivation later when he traps Aladdin for not giving him the lamp fast enough.
option_D_explanation: Incorrect. What he told the mother was part of his deception. The text says 'the stranger was not really Aladdin's uncle at all' and he lied to gain trust. His words do not show his real goal - his actions of trapping Aladdin do.

article_title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I
question: How do the magician's actions in the beginning of the story lead to Aladdin getting trapped?
option_A: The magician lies about being family so Aladdin will trust and obey him
option_B: The magician teaches Aladdin how to use magic spells incorrectly
option_C: The magician forces Aladdin to steal gems from the cave
option_D: The magician tells Aladdin's mother to send her son away
option_A_explanation: Correct! The text shows the magician 'was not really Aladdin's uncle at all' but pretended to be family. He 'wanted to find a person who would follow his directions without asking too many questions.' By lying about being family, he gained trust so Aladdin would obey him and go into the cave. This deception at the beginning leads directly to Aladdin being trapped when he cannot immediately give the lamp.
option_B_explanation: Incorrect. The magician does not teach Aladdin any magic. The text shows the magician performed magic himself and gave Aladdin a protective ring, but he never taught the boy how to use spells. Aladdin gets trapped because of the magician's impatience, not incorrect magic use.
option_C_explanation: Incorrect. The magician did not force Aladdin to take gems. The text says 'Once you have the lamp, you may take any treasures you want,' giving Aladdin permission. Aladdin chose to fill his bag with gems, which made it heavy, but the magician's impatience about getting the lamp caused the trapping.
option_D_explanation: Incorrect. The text shows the mother 'welcomed the man into their home' and 'believed his words,' but he did not tell her to send Aladdin away. He deceived both of them by pretending to be family, and this deception enabled everything that followed.

article_title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I
question: Based on the story, why does the magician choose Aladdin specifically instead of going into the cave himself?
option_A: He needs someone young who will follow orders without questioning
option_B: He is too old and weak to climb down into the cave
option_C: He believes only someone from Persia can touch the lamp
option_D: He wants to teach Aladdin how to become rich first
option_A_explanation: Correct! The text explains that 'To find this lamp, the magician needed someone to help him. He wanted to find a person who would follow his directions without asking too many questions. He thought Aladdin was exactly the right person for this job.' The magician chose Aladdin because he could manipulate a poor boy into obeying him completely.
option_B_explanation: Incorrect. The text never suggests the magician is too weak. In fact, he climbs the steep mountain with Aladdin. The text clearly states he needed someone 'who would follow his directions without asking too many questions,' not someone to do physical work he could not do.
option_C_explanation: Incorrect. The text does not mention any rule about only people from Persia touching the lamp. The magician came 'from far away in North Africa' specifically to find the lamp, so location is not the reason he needed help.
option_D_explanation: Incorrect. The magician's promise to help Aladdin become a merchant was a lie to gain trust. The text says 'the stranger was not really Aladdin's uncle at all' and he only wanted 'to get the lamp.' Teaching Aladdin was never his real goal.

article_title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I
question: What evidence from the story shows that the magician never intended to help Aladdin become wealthy?
option_A: He becomes angry and traps Aladdin instead of helping him out of the cave
option_B: He travels from North Africa to Persia searching for the lamp
option_C: He brings Aladdin to a remote mountain instead of the city marketplace
option_D: He gives Aladdin a special protective ring before entering the cave
option_A_explanation: Correct! The text states 'The magician grew very angry. He only cared about getting the magic lamp.' When Aladdin needed help climbing out, the magician demanded the lamp first. When Aladdin could not give it immediately, the magician 'spoke a magic spell, and the stone rolled back into place,' trapping him. A person who truly wanted to help Aladdin become wealthy would have helped him out of the cave, but instead the magician abandoned him when he did not get what he wanted.
option_B_explanation: Incorrect. His long journey shows his determination to find the lamp for himself, but does not directly prove he would not help Aladdin. The clearest evidence of his true intentions comes from his actions when Aladdin needs help - he traps the boy instead of assisting him.
option_C_explanation: Incorrect. Going to the mountain was necessary because that is where the lamp was hidden. This does not prove he would not help Aladdin - he needed to go there to get the lamp. His trapping of Aladdin at the end provides the strongest evidence of his selfish intentions.
option_D_explanation: Incorrect. Giving Aladdin the ring might seem like he was helping, but the text explains he needed Aladdin safe to retrieve the lamp. The ring served the magician's purpose. The real evidence of his selfishness is when he traps Aladdin rather than helping him out of the cave.

article_title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I
question: What is the central message or lesson of this story about Aladdin and the magician?
option_A: Magic can solve all of your problems if you believe in it.
option_B: Be careful about trusting strangers who make big promises.
option_C: Hard work is the only way to become wealthy and successful.
option_D: Always listen to your mother's advice about strangers.
option_A_explanation: You may have focused on the word “magic,” but look at how the magician lies about being Aladdin’s uncle, promises riches, and then uses magic to trap Aladdin in the cave—believing in magic doesn’t solve his problems, it creates them. This shows the real lesson is to be careful about trusting strangers who make big promises. Next time, check that your answer matches what happens in the whole story, especially the results of the characters’ actions.
option_B_explanation: You successfully identified the lesson by noticing how a stranger’s big promises led to trouble. The text supports this when the man promises to help Aladdin “learn to become a merchant and earn good money” and says the treasure will make him “richer than any king in the world,” but then he traps Aladdin in the cave. Remember, when finding a story’s lesson, ask yourself, “What happens after a character makes a big promise?”
option_C_explanation: You may have focused on the detail that Aladdin’s mother works hard, but the story’s events point to a different lesson. Aladdin doesn’t become rich through hard work—the stranger pretends to be his uncle, promises to make him a merchant, then uses magic and traps Aladdin in the cave to get the lamp. This shows the real lesson: be careful about trusting strangers who make big promises. Strategy: Reread the whole passage and ask, “What warning does the story give?” so your answer matches the main message, not just one detail.
option_D_explanation: You might be thinking about what parents usually say about strangers, but in the story the mother doesn’t give advice—she believes the “uncle,” and he is really a magician. The man promises Aladdin he will “earn good money” and find a treasure “richer than any king,” then he tricks Aladdin and traps him, so the lesson is to be careful about trusting strangers who make big promises. Next time, reread and ask, “What lesson fits what actually happens in the whole story?”

article_title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I
question: What lesson does this story teach about accepting help from people you just met?
option_A: Strangers who offer easy money may have hidden reasons for helping you
option_B: Family members always tell the truth about their identity
option_C: Poor people should accept any help offered to them
option_D: Magic can help you solve problems if you trust the right person
option_A_explanation: Correct! The story shows how the magician lied about being Aladdin's uncle and promised to help him become rich, but really only wanted the lamp for himself. The text says 'the stranger was not really Aladdin's uncle at all' and shows he trapped Aladdin when he did not get what he wanted. The central lesson is to be cautious about strangers who make big promises because they may be trying to use you, just like the reference question teaches.
option_B_explanation: Incorrect. This story actually teaches the opposite - the magician lied about being family! The text clearly states 'the stranger was not really Aladdin's uncle at all' and 'She felt very surprised because her husband had never told her about having a brother.' The lesson is about being careful, not about trusting family claims.
option_C_explanation: Incorrect. The story shows that accepting help without questioning can be dangerous. Aladdin accepted the magician's help and ended up trapped in a cave. The lesson is to be cautious and thoughtful, not to accept all help offered.
option_D_explanation: Incorrect. Magic is not the lesson here. The magician used magic to trap Aladdin, not help him. The story teaches about being careful with strangers who make promises, not about trusting people with magic.

article_title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I
question: Which detail from the story best supports the message about being careful with people who seem too generous?
option_A: The magician promises to help Aladdin become a merchant but really wants the lamp
option_B: Aladdin's father worked as a tailor making clothes for people
option_C: The magician uses sweet-smelling perfumes and magical words to open the earth
option_D: Aladdin finds a lamp hanging from a tree in a beautiful garden
option_A_explanation: Correct! This detail directly supports the story's warning about generous strangers. The text shows the magician promised 'to help Aladdin learn to become a merchant and earn good money' but 'was not really Aladdin's uncle at all' and 'only cared about getting the magic lamp.' His false generosity to gain Aladdin's trust is the key detail that conveys the lesson about being cautious.
option_B_explanation: Incorrect. Information about Aladdin's father's job helps establish that the family is poor, but does not relate to the lesson about being careful with overly generous strangers. This detail provides background, not the central message.
option_C_explanation: Incorrect. The magical opening of the earth is an exciting story event, but does not convey the lesson about trusting generous strangers. The important detail is the magician's false promises and deception, not his magical abilities.
option_D_explanation: Incorrect. Finding the lamp is part of the plot, but does not support the message about caution with strangers. The key detail is how the magician deceived Aladdin with false promises of help, not the description of where the lamp was located.

article_title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I
question: How does the author use the magician's actions throughout the story to teach a lesson about trust?
option_A: By showing he lies about his identity, makes promises, then betrays Aladdin
option_B: By describing how he uses powerful magic spells and perfumes
option_C: By explaining that he traveled a very long distance to find the lamp
option_D: By revealing that he gives Aladdin a special ring for protection
option_A_explanation: Correct! The author builds the lesson through a pattern of the magician's deceptive actions. First, 'the stranger was not really Aladdin's uncle at all.' Then he promises to 'help Aladdin learn to become a merchant and earn good money.' Finally, when Aladdin cannot give him the lamp immediately, 'He spoke a magic spell, and the stone rolled back into place' trapping him. This sequence of lying, promising, and betraying teaches readers to be cautious about trusting strangers.
option_B_explanation: Incorrect. While the magician's magic makes the story exciting, describing his spells does not teach the lesson about trust. The lesson comes from showing how he deceives Aladdin with false promises, not from his magical abilities.
option_C_explanation: Incorrect. His long journey shows his determination but does not teach about trust. The lesson is conveyed through his pattern of lying about being family, making promises to help Aladdin, then betraying him when he gets what he wants.
option_D_explanation: Incorrect. Giving Aladdin the ring might seem generous, but the text explains he needed Aladdin protected to get the lamp. The lesson about trust comes from showing his overall pattern of deception and betrayal, not from one seemingly helpful act.

option_A: So he can help Aladdin become a rich merchant.

The correct answer is that he wanted Aladdin to bring him the magic lamp. Next time, check the character’s actions and repeated clues, not just their first promise.

This shows he pretended to be family to get Aladdin to bring him the lamp, which is the correct answer. article_title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I
question: Why does the author include the detail that the magician comes from 'far away in North Africa' to find the lamp?
option_A: To show how desperately he wants the lamp and will go to great lengths to get it
option_B: To explain why he does not know Aladdin's family well
option_C: To describe the long journey that made him very tired
option_D: To teach readers about different countries and their customs
option_A_explanation: Correct! The text explains the magician 'had traveled from far away in North Africa' and 'had come all the way to Persia to search for a special magic lamp.' This detail emphasizes the magician's obsessive desire for the lamp - he traveled enormous distances, which reveals his true priority. This helps convey the message that he never cared about Aladdin, only about getting the lamp. His willingness to travel so far and deceive people shows his selfish determination.
option_B_explanation: Incorrect. While coming from far away could explain not knowing the family, this is not why the author includes this detail. The magician lied about being the brother anyway. The detail emphasizes his extreme determination to get the lamp, which supports the lesson about his selfish motives.
option_C_explanation: Incorrect. The text does not describe the magician as tired. In fact, he energetically climbs a mountain with Aladdin. The detail about his distant origin shows his obsessive pursuit of the lamp and supports the message about his deception, not about being tired.
option_D_explanation: Incorrect. This is a folk tale, not an informational text about countries. The author mentions North Africa to emphasize the extreme lengths the magician will go to get what he wants, which supports the story's lesson about being cautious with self-serving strangers.

article_title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I
question: What is the magician's real reason for pretending to be part of Aladdin's family?
option_A: To make Aladdin trust him so the boy will help retrieve the magic lamp
option_B: To become close friends with Aladdin and teach him about magic
option_C: To find out if Aladdin's father left behind any valuable treasures
option_D: To move to Persia and start a new life with a loving family
option_A_explanation: Correct! The text clearly explains his deception and motive: 'the stranger was not really Aladdin's uncle at all. He was actually a powerful magician' who 'needed someone to help him' find the lamp. He 'wanted to find a person who would follow his directions without asking too many questions.' By pretending to be family, he gained trust so Aladdin would obey him and enter the dangerous cave to get the lamp.
option_B_explanation: Incorrect. The magician never wanted friendship or to teach Aladdin. The text says 'He only cared about getting the magic lamp.' Everything he did was to trick Aladdin into helping him get the lamp, not to build a genuine relationship.
option_C_explanation: Incorrect. The text never suggests Aladdin's father had treasures. In fact, the story establishes the family was poor - the father was 'a tailor' and the mother 'had to work hard to earn money.' The magician wanted the magic lamp in the cave, not anything from Aladdin's father.
option_D_explanation: Incorrect. The magician 'had traveled from far away in North Africa' specifically to 'search for a special magic lamp,' not to find a family. He lied about being family as a trick to manipulate Aladdin, and the text shows 'He only cared about getting the magic lamp.'

article_title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I
question: How does the magician's behavior at the end of the story reveal his true character and purpose?
option_A: He abandons Aladdin when he cannot get the lamp immediately, showing he only cared about the treasure
option_B: He gives detailed instructions about not touching treasures, showing he wants to keep Aladdin safe
option_C: He uses magic to open the earth, showing he has powerful abilities from studying for years
option_D: He climbs the steep mountain with Aladdin, showing he is willing to work hard for his goals
option_A_explanation: Correct! The text shows his true nature in the final paragraph: 'The magician grew very angry. He only cared about getting the magic lamp.' When Aladdin needed help climbing out but could not hand over the lamp right away, the 'impatient magician could not wait any longer. He spoke a magic spell, and the stone rolled back into place. Poor Aladdin was trapped in the dark cave below.' His willingness to trap a child reveals he never intended to help Aladdin - he only wanted the lamp for himself.
option_B_explanation: Incorrect. His instructions were not about safety - he told Aladdin not to touch treasures because 'To find this lamp, the magician needed someone to help him' and he wanted Aladdin focused on getting the lamp. His behavior at the end, trapping Aladdin, proves he did not care about the boy's safety.
